title: YouTuber Jack Harries celebrates being found not guilty after arrest
text:
Jack has been found not guilty (Pictures: Instagram/Twitter)

YouTuber and activist Jack Harries has been found not guilty after he was arrested in February at a non-violent climate change protest.

The internet star, who built a huge following with his twin brother Finn, took to social media to celebrate the news.

‘Eight months ago, I was arrested for peacefully protesting outside the International Petroleum Conference in London,’ he wrote.

‘I was held in a cell for twelve hours and charged with criminal damage and aggravated trespass along-side eight other activists.

‘Since then, we have been in and out of court five times over seven months. I know this process has significantly impacted the lives of many of the defendants involved, including myself.

‘Today I’m overjoyed to say that I was found ‘not guilty’ for my actions. Five of us were found ‘not guilty’, while four were found ‘guilty’ of trespass and given a twelve-month conditional discharge.’

Jack went on to acknowledge that being arrested comes with a higher risk for some demographics and explained that he didn’t intend to ‘glamorise’ it.

The 26-year-old added: ‘During the last twelve months, @extinctionrebellion has been successful in bringing the climate crisis to the forefront of public awareness and conversation. This would not have have been possible without those willing to sacrifice their liberty in the name of this movement.’

The YouTuber was arrested earlier this year (Picture: @extinctionrebellion)

Jack was arrested as he attended International Petroleum Week in London, where oil and gas industry leaders came together to address the industry.

He boasts four million followers on his JacksGap YouTube channel and has made several films about environmental destruction.

Jack also supported Jane Fonda after she was arrested (Picture: The Washington Post via Getty Images)

Since, the star has supported Jane Fonda, who was recently arrested in Washington DC at a climate change protest.

‘Amazing interview by @camanpour with Jane Fonda, who has vowed to be arrested every Friday to raise awareness of climate change, in a country where the president doesn’t even believe it’s an issue,’ he wrote.

‘This is a powerful example of activism!!!’ he wrote.

The Grace and Frankie star told the Washington Post she was inspired by 16-year-old activist Greta Thunberg, and added that the teen had ‘realised what was happening and that this was barreling at us like an engine’.
